statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({2}^{{-{x}+{4}}}\right)}+{1}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={2}{\left({2}^{{-{x}+{4}}}\right)}+{1} has \displaystyle+{1} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={1}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle-{x}+{4}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}={4}. Here \displaystyle{y}={3}.
A second convenient point is one left of 4, which is \displaystyle{x}={3}. Here \displaystyle{y}={5}
